item.title: 4G Wireless Broadband Wars This Year
item.description: The race for 4G dominance is about to start, even though 3G deployment is still underway. Major carriers like AT&T, Verizon, and Sprint have upgraded most of their towers in populated areas, and 3G devices are readily available. However, the focus is shifting to 4G due to the increasing demand for bandwidth from sophisticated mobile applications and the ongoing competition among carriers. The value of 4G lies in its potential to enable future advancements rather than just meeting current needs.

item.title: Speedier Network For The iPhone
item.description: While the iPhone’s popularity is a boon for AT&T, which holds the exclusive contract, the device’s data demands present a significant hurdle. Historically, cellular towers primarily handled voice calls, with data as a secondary function. Early data speeds were adequate for text-based services, but the advent of camera phones, web browsers, and video streaming dramatically increased bandwidth requirements. Today’s users demand home and work-level speeds, typically between 3 to 10 Mbps, far exceeding the capabilities of older networks.

item.title: HSUPA Joins HSDPA for Cellular Broadband
item.description: AT&T is nearing completion of its enhanced cellular broadband network, known as HSPA (High Speed Packet Access). This advancement is timely, as the latest BlackBerry Bold and the anticipated upgraded iPhone will utilize the increased data speeds now available. Although most attention has been on download enhancements, AT&T has also been quietly improving upload capabilities, hinting at the potential of upcoming mobile applications. HSPA is an upgrade within the complex world of mobile technology.

item.title: Cell Phone Plans With Aircards
item.description: Wireless modem aircards liberate you from the constraints of WiFi hotspots, transforming your laptop into a truly mobile computer. But how do they work, and what kind of service plans are necessary? Essentially, an aircard functions as a specialized two-way radio, transmitting and receiving digital computer data instead of voice calls. While they might resemble them, aircards don’t operate on cell phone networks. Currently, the majority adhere to either EVDO (Sprint and Verizon Wireless) or EDGE and HSPA (AT&T and T-Mobile) standards for cellular broadband.

item.title: 4G Wireless Quietly Encroaching on 3G
item.description: Cellular companies are promoting 3G wireless technology as the most advanced available. However, a faster technology called 4G is being gradually introduced across the country. This situation reflects the typical progression of technology, where an invention like wireless data service undergoes continuous advancements. Like early personal computers compared to today’s models, mobile data is following a similar path of growth. Cellular carriers dominate wide-area mobile service due to their extensive network infrastructure.

item.title: T-Mobile G2 With Google is 4G
item.description: T-Mobile is raising the bar for smartphones with its new G2, a Google phone that seamlessly integrates with Google Voice. This allows for voicemails to be converted to text and read like emails or texts. Powered by Android 2.2, the G2 boasts a 3.7-inch full touch screen with seven customizable home panels. Users can personalize their experience with thousands of apps and widgets from the Android Market. One of the G2’s standout features is its Adobe Flash Player, unlike a well-known competitor.

item.title: AT&T HSUPA Aircards Have the Edge Over EDGE
item.description: Major wireless carriers, including AT&T, are heavily invested in upgrading their cellular data capabilities to meet the increasing demand for broadband internet access. This demand stems from the desire for constant connectivity, enabling activities like web browsing and mobile video streaming. AT&T is eager to capitalize on this demand and provide the desired connectivity. Those accustomed to traditional wired broadband connections and basic cell phones may not fully grasp the advancements in mobile broadband technology.

item.title: Fixed Wireless Moving To 4G
item.description: Fixed wireless broadband for businesses has two main forms. The first, found primarily in downtown areas of major cities, uses licensed microwave services. While this method offers high bandwidth, it has a limited coverage area of a few thousand feet and requires a clear line of sight. The second approach utilizes existing 3G cellular broadband networks to provide wider coverage, comparable to a T1 line’s bandwidth, wherever there’s a cell phone signal.

item.title: I'm Not Paying For That Aircard
item.description: Fast and dependable office internet connections are great when you’re stationary, but mobile work demands solutions like WiFi hotspots or cellular broadband. While these options are suitable, not all laptops are equipped for cellular broadband. Aircards, sometimes called wireless modems, bridge this gap. Similar to WiFi access cards, these devices allow laptops to connect to cellular broadband networks. In the past, laptops primarily used built-in modems, requiring separate cards for WiFi.

item.title: Cell Phone Wireless Broadband
item.description: Cell phones today are capable of much more than just voice calls. The mobile networks have evolved to carry both voice and data, offering wireless broadband internet access that rivals DSL and cable connections. If you haven’t explored mobile internet recently, you might be surprised by its speed and availability. Currently, two competing systems are widely available, with two even faster networks in their early stages. AT&T promotes its HSDPA and EDGE networks, notably featuring the Apple iPhone.
